Award.AwardTitle: Light reconfigurable near field acoustic manipulation for high resolution construction of biological tissues

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
3D in vitro cell culture systems have evolved from simple 3D collagen gel matrices to complex, multi-cell models with controlled mechanical, chemical, and biological cues. High throughput methods such as bioplotting, and bioprinting can build large samples but lack resolution. On the other end, high precision approaches such as optical tweezers, electrokinetic patterning, acoustic patterning, and microcontact printing are available, but limited to patterning in small length scales. Currently, there is no effective method for multiscale manipulation of biological objects of sizes from single cells, cell colonies, and cell aggregates. This proposal aims to investigate and develop an efficient platform capable of overcoming this technical barrier for precision manipulation and patterning of fragile biological objects of sizes across multiple scales. The new cell and colony patterning ability will allow constructing tissues with higher detail and cellular organization to mimic the true composition and microenvironment between human physiologies. Besides obvious applications in tissue regeneration and drug screening, the new patterning capability can provide new insights into intriguing scientific questions. Results and expertise developed during the course of this project will also be incorporated into PI's teaching activities at both the undergraduate and graduate levels. Undergraduate students will participate in these projects through independent research courses. The PIs will also collaborate with the High School Summer Research Program at UCLA to recruit local K12 students for summer internship in PIs' lab.

Acoustic manipulation has shown its potential for patterning and manipulating single cells and large-sized objects. However, dynamic patterning and control of acoustic field is more difficult than other approaches using electric fields and optical fields. Currently, dynamic acoustic trapping and manipulation of cells are accomplished by using pairs of interdigitated transducers (IDT) electrodes coupled with broadband excitation signals. However, this approach has limited degree-of-freedom (DOF) and cannot construct complex acoustic field landscape. This proposal aims to investigate and develop a novel light reconfigured acoustic patterning mechanism that can provide precision manipulation and patterning of fragile biological objects of sizes spanning over 2 orders of magnitude from 10 Ã¬m to 1 mm. Research projects include the investigation of the fundamentals of defects induced trapping behaviors and their limitations; the development of light reconfigured structure defects for dynamic manipulation and patterning, and the platform's application for high throughput construction of multiscale biological tissues of complex patterns.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Acoustic manipulation of biological samples has attracted much interest in the past decade for its excellent biocompatibility compared to other physical mechanisms that utilize electrical, optical, and magnetical forms of energy. Biological objects such as cells, colonies, and biomolecules can be moved under the application of an acoustic field. These movements are driven either by acoustic radiation forces in an acoustic field with non-uniform intensity distribution or fluid drag forces driven by acoustically induced streaming flows. Conventionally, generations of acoustic fields are usually achieved by two methods, surface acoustic wave (SAW) and bulk acoustic wave(BAW). These mechanisms, however, suffer some drawbacks. SAW manipulation is limited to small areas due to the decay of acoustic energy during propagation. The acoustic field patterns that can be generated by SAW are also limited due to the limilted crystalline orientations available in the piezoelectric materials. BAW manipulation has limited spatial resolution due to the wavelength of acoustic waves used for forming standing acoustic waves constrained by the device structure. Applying high frequency waves increases the heat dissipation in structure vibration beyond the tolerable range. 

The goals of this grant are to investigate a new acoustic field generation mechanism that can realize large area acoustic manipulation with non-periodic shaped acoustic landscapes and near field patterning that can realize high spatial resolution manipulation without using high frequency acoustic waves to limit heat generation. 

Through the conduction of research projects proposed in the grant, our team has successfully demonstrated a new acoustic platform, called Compliant Membrane Acoustic Platform (CMAP), capable of realizing the above mentioned features. CMAP is a simple structure fabricated with widely used PDMS polymer and glass. A plandary acoustic wave emitted from a PZT substrate propagates through pre-patterned air cavities in the polymer structure (Fig. 1). These air cavities, due to their large acoustic mismatch with the surrounding, effectively prevent acoustic wave propagation through them and generate low acoustic field regions behind them. This creates non-uniform acoustic field strength distribution across the device surface and radiation forces for microscale objects near the surface. Since the patterns of these low acoustic field regions nearly match with the shapes of pre-patterned air cavities. Complex and non-periodic acoustic field landscapes are created. Furthermore, since these are near field acoustic patterns, they can generate a spatial resolution of 1/10 the acoustic wavelength used. Examples shown are 50μm resolution using an acoustic wavelength of 500μm(Fig. 2). 

Furthermore, we have also accomplished the development of a light re-configurable acoustic platform called Field Programmable Acoustic Array (FPAA). The underline physical mechanism of FPAA is based on CMAP. The difference is that all the air cavities on the FPAA platform have a square shape. The thin film PDMS membrane on each cavity allows it to be filled with water under a vacuum condition. The water filled in each cavity can be reversely converted back to the air cavity state under laser irradiation to vaporize the water. Since the water filled cavities have acoustic impedance close to the surrounding polymer structure and water medium, acoustic waves can propagate through them without much attenuation. FPAA provides a platform that can be digitally programmed to generate different acoustic field landscapes for different applications. 

 

This grant has supported a PhD student to finish his degree and several undergraduate students to gain research experience through conducting hands-on fabrication and running numerical simulation for acoustic wave modeling. The results of these research works have been published in several peer-reviewed journals for dissemination.
